title: Duplicate SampleRecord/CalibrationInfo definitions cause schema mismatch
description: Found in cof_tester-rcg: Two conflicting definitions exist. protocols/__init__.py defines tuple-based frozen dataclasses, while models.py defines numpy array-based dataclasses. Protocol modules (rdt_udp.py, tcp_cmd.py, http_calibration.py) import from models.py, but tests import from protocols/__init__.py. Tests pass but test the wrong implementation. rdt_udp.py yields SampleRecord with numpy counts, but if consumer code imports from protocols, it expects tuple counts. Fix: Remove duplicate definitions from protocols/__init__.py and re-export from models.py, or consolidate to one canonical location.

title: AsyncFileWriter: Inconsistent header line endings for Excel format

This results in mixed line endings in the output file (header uses LF, rows use CRLF), which violates the Excel-compatible requirement for consistent CRLF.

title: HTTP calibration XML parsing broken by ElementTree boolean bug
description: Found in cof_tester-kdl: In parse_calibration_xml(), lines 102-103 use 'or' chains to search for XML elements with fallback names. However, ElementTree elements with no children (like <cfgcpf>1000</cfgcpf>) evaluate to False in boolean context, causing the 'or' to skip the found element and continue searching. This means parse_calibration_xml always fails with 'Missing counts_per_force in calibration XML' even with valid XML. The fix: use 'if x is None:' instead of 'or' chains, e.g.: cpf_element = root.find('.//cfgcpf'); if cpf_element is None: cpf_element = root.find('.//countsPerForce'); etc.
